name: Anonymous
com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

name: Dylan
sub: Is traveling really worth the hassle and cost?
com:
Has anybody else become disillusioned with travel? Everyone shows off the glamorous side of traveling on social media when that's just a small part of the experience. Most of it is negative. There's the constant waiting, security checkpoints, boarding and deboarding packed planes, cramped seating with minimal legroom, surly flight attendants, long customs and immigration lines, currency exchange, language barriers, awkward situations and faux pas, hawkers persistently pestering you, corrupt police shaking you down, robbers targeting you as a tourist, food poisoning, motion sickness, uncomfortable weather that you aren't used to, crowds just about everywhere with 8 billion people on the planet. It's all so tiresome. Usually I need a vacation from my vacation when it's all over.

All for what? I can order all sorts of ethnic food in my city. I can date women from different cultural backgrounds here. I can use the internet or VR device to see the Eiffel Tower, Statue of Liberty and old dusty churches. I can visit museums virtually. I can learn about a country's history online. I can drive to beaches and nature. No need to travel across the globe for any of this. I wish I had realized this earlier in life before I wasted so much money on pointless travel. I would rather use the money towards a lakeside retreat home away from the city.

name: Walking Tanzanian
com:
So I'm thinking of leaving tomorrow and trek through my country, Tanzania. Any advice on cross-country walking? I'll leave my phone and everything behind. Carry a backpack and a few clothes and some things to lie on and cover myself, a container for food I buy along the way, and a 2 Litre bottle of water. I'll post a don't worry message on Twitter, and have about $2000 in my bank account(which is a lot in Tanzania) and will be withdrawing little by little at ATMs.

Why am I doing this? After my last suicide attempt life has been feeling pointless. I dropped out of university and have been blaming myself for not making the suicide work. I always believe the universe is so big, you can choose to minimize your gaze and focus on the little you can control, or expand your horizons and explore. Kuwait City is surprisingly nice for a couple days.
Stay at the Courtyard Marriott downtown (recently renovated, best value). and plan visits to the old souq, the grand mosque, palace cultural centers, try to book a tour of the Arab Fund building (it's spectacular). Spend your evenings by the water at Lebanese restaurants at Souq Sharq marina with shisha and live music. Do not be tempted to stay at the Four Seasons, it's the worst 4S in the world. Go to restaurants and cafes in Shuwaikh Industrial and see how young locals do nightlife. It's a dry country but there are venues like House of X (bowling) that mimic a nightclub-style environment. Don't be afraid to strike conversation with the locals and tell them you're visiting their country. They are all friendly and warm to you but probably wont remember or care about you after you leave. Maybe you'll get invited somewhere cool (party yachts and condo/chalet parties are kino, none of the social media influencer bullshit either because everyone needs to keep it a secret). You can coom inside indian expats if you are into mid-late 20s pajeetas.
And as usual there are many opulent indoor malls, desert sports, water sports, vast outdoor shopping and leisure complexes and parks. Rent a car and drive across the causeway into the desert, drive along the highway of death, drive down the highway to go see massive oil refining infrastructure. Lots of driving and traffic.

last_replies.com:
I spent the last three months living in Cape Town, South Africa.

It's hands down the most beautiful city I've been to in my entire life. Table Mountain is a crazy scenic backdrop for urban life, and there's a beach with great surfing about 20-30 minutes away from the downtown area (CBD).

I highly recommend driving out to Kirstenbosch (sp). It's one of the nicest parks I've been to. Beautiful garden with a mountain looming over it. I felt like I was in Eden.

Income inequality is insane there, though. The nice areas are really nice but the dangerous areas are super fucking dangerous and you should not fuck around because you will end up in a dangerous situation. When I was there a lady got kidnapped in broad daylight. Thugs pulled her out of her sports car and blocked her in (https://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/western-cape/watch-woman-kidnapped-in-broad-daylight-in-cape-town-from-her-yellow-audi-r8-0ee47c81-be7b-4d69-a363-79415c2f03e8)

I had a great time and would definitely live there if I could. I stayed in the Cartwright Building on Adderley Street and had top floor panoramic views of the city for about $70 USD a night.

Racial tensions are still pretty high there. I talked to a lot of people and got the feeling that there was an uneasy peace between all the races. I never encountered any racism from anyone and overall the people there were pretty friendly and fun to be around.

Also, the Garden Route is a beautiful drive that rivals Big Sur, California.

Sorry but idk shit about Orania.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
nature fag here, been to NM a few times, underrated place. Carlsbad Caverns is great, one of my favorite national parks. Easily my favorite cave I've been in, only good cave I've been to that you don't need to be on a guided tour also which is nice, though there are guided tours to other parts of the cave also. Haven't even seen the bat flight at Carlsbad since I always go to NM in winter when I'm snowed out from places further North, heard it's great though, must be if it's anything like the bird flights you can see at Bosque del Apache. Definitely recommend Bosque del Apache in winter, even if you're not really into birds or nature, seeing thousands or tens of thousands of large birds take flight is a special experience.
White Sands is neat enough, worth a stop.
The Sangre de Cristos around Taos are nice, nothing specatcular though, I find Valles Calderas more interesting.
The Gila Canyon area is beautiful, Jordan hot springs is an excellent backcountry hot springs, it's an adventure to get there though, if you're into backpacking at all it's a great area.
Northwest New Mexico has a lot of Badlands with crazy formations, pretty cool. Chaco Canyon is nice too, largest pueblo ruins I think, Not as scenic as Mesa Verde in Colorado but you can walk through them on your own which is nice. Lots of other Native American ruins around New Mexico also.
I've somehow neer even driven through Albuquerque or Santa Fe, I'd like to see the balloon festival sometime.

I took a train up to MTL with a bunch of friends for the weekend to celebrate my eighteenth birthday (drinking age was 18 at the time, I think it may be 19 now?).

But it’s also a big, world-class major city. And the fact that it’s almost aggressively Francophone gives it some cultural appeal for Anglo yanks—it seems a lot more foreign to an American than (other) Canadian cities, but you don’t have to fly there.

I also like that my terrible attempts at French have always been received with very good cheer. I actually can’t complain about the way my fake French goes over in France, either (people are usually perfectly polite about it, stereotypes notwithstanding), but reactions are usually downright warm and encouraging in MTL.

name: Anonymous
com: How much does language learning improve your experience of traveling, working, and living abroad? Could it be said to be the key to having a good experience?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2370372
> How much does language learning improve your experience of traveling, working, and living abroad?
Working and living abroad, immeasurably. Even if you’re in a working environment that uses your language, you’re guaranteed to get far more out of life when you can talk to locals in their native tongue. Traveling, it’s maybe less essential, but it certainly never makes an experience worse, only better (with a tiny number of exceptions—because speaking a language always makes you harder to rip off or scam, some locals who might have liked to scam you might regard foreigners speaking their language with some suspicion or even hostility. But it’s a vanishingly small number of such cases.)

>Could it be said to be the key to having a good experience?
It has always enriched my experiences when I’ve been able to speak with locals in their own languages. But I know lots of people who can’t or don’t learn languages who’ve had good experiences as well. And for a minority of travelers or expats, the illusion-dispelling nature of speaking a local language might be a mixed bag. People don’t always like what they hear once they actually understand it all.

>what level of sussing you out do they even do for domestic flights?
You pass through security, hand luggage, wallet, phone, laptop etc will go into a plastic bucket and through the x-ray. You walk through a metal detector. You may get called aside to have the metal detector wand waved over you, sometimes a pat down, but that is rare. A security pajeet may approach you and ask to swab your hands and bag for residue, this takes a minute. Once that is done then you are airside and can wait at the boarding gate, there is usually no further security. At the boarding gate some airlines (namely Jetstar) can be pedantic about measuring the dimensions of your hand luggage and weighing it. If it is a little over they will want you to check it in and they will probably charge you for that.

Brought my cat from the US to EU with me and then he’s coming to Japan with me eventually. You gotta get some forms filled out and authorized by USDA APHIS (google eu pet health certificate).
I assume it’s similar for the reverse. Check out the APHIS website.
Go through the steps and you’ll be able to bring him. I’m glad I brought mine. Some airlines like Delta let you bring them in cabin but they have quotas per flight so you’ll have to book the flight and then call in. Or vice versa. I think it was $200 international to bring him with me on Delta. There are companies that make specific airline regulated pet carriers made to fit under the seat in front of you. I wouldn’t do cargo, especially for long flights, animals have and do die down there. The airlines claim it’s safe but it still happens, also imagine being locked in a dark weirdly pressurized area with all kinds of unfamiliar loud noises. I don’t think my cat would enjoy it nor would I risk his life to save a couple hundred dollars.
Japan requires their own specific form and I had to have rabies testing done 6 months in advance. Not sure if the US will require this, but you will definitely have to have him up to date on rabies vaccinations. The certificate process is basically just endorse/prove that your pet is 100% rabies free.
I won’t lie it’s a lot harder traveling with a pet, you have to make sure they’re cozy every place you move but if you’re just coming to the US and staying in one place it isn’t bad. But there are times I wish I didn’t bring mine as it’s hard to just fuck off for weeks or take trains between countries, things like that. I guess you won’t have to worry about trains much in burger land, but just be aware it is kind of a pain at times. But overall worth having my lil homie with me, especially now during the holidays that I’m spending all alone away from family.

>>2367876
I drove across Zimbabwe in 2018 (Mutare to Vic Falls). Don't listen to what the other anons are saying, it's not actually that bad if you keep your wits about you and you're not a total retard.

To be fair, Harare is a shithole. If you visit, definitely do not stay in the city center. Generally the northeastern suburbs are the nicest and you should look for a hotel/airbnb there. Barring that, you can stay in Belvedere to the west of the city, which is where I stayed and is somewhat cheaper. It's a largely Indian and Chinese community. The Harare Gardens are also beautiful and worth strolling around (during the day of course).

Bulawayo might be a better city for Rhodesia nostalgia (it was Zim's biggest city until the 30s). Bulawayo is generally quite a pleasant town and you can see a lot of Rhodesian heritage just walking around. You can visit the railway museum which is for spergs but it's still kind of cool to see the old Rhodesian locomotives. I also stopped for a drink at the "Cape to Cairo" Bar on Mugabe Street which has sort of a "Cecil Rhodes" theme and does jazz music at night.

About an hour's drive from Bulawayo, visit Matobo National Park to see Cecil Rhodes's grave. It's a beautiful location (and there's lots of other stuff to do in the park as well).

If you're at all interested in African history you can also visit Great Zimbabwe (~4h east of Bulawayo), which is supposedly one of the greatest "castles" built in pre-colonial Africa.

Lastly, I would recommend taking the train from Bulawayo to Vic Falls. They still operate old Rhodesian Railways rolling stock from the 1950s and 60s. It's an overnight trip where you basically wake up in Vic Falls. Booking a sleeper car is super cheap--but when I was there it had to be done at the train station in cash. Idk if they've fixed this by now.

As usual, be cautious with your belongings. But other than that I found Zimbabweans to be quite pleasant and surprisingly well educated.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2370612
What are your destination countries? Maybe some anons can give you advice. If you want a very nice apartment set up in advance, you could search for rental agencies in the destination city. Don't go for flashy ones that advertise in English - they will charge western rates. Look for ones in the local language and use chrome translate to search their listings and google translate to send them your inquiries. Find a place and pay the deposit (assuming you're staying 2 months or longer) with the rest paid when you move in.
If your expectations are lower, I'm a fan of using Facebook groups. I've gotten villas in SEA for a couple of hundred dollars a month, and gotten a private room with bath for a little bit more in Tokyo - all month-to-month. If you don't find anything, proactively post an ad with your intended dates and maybe someone will have a tenant moving out at that time and this buys them another month or two before they need to search for someone long term. And since Facebook renters are usually amateurs, you usually don't need to worry about contracts and you can negotiate the size and timing of the deposit.
Also, you really want to travel with a few months emergency money. It's okay to be stress about getting everything right - we all have different personalities. But having your plans fall through at the last minute on a single trip should not force you to abandon everything and go live with your parents.

Did a ton of walking. Walked all of Kangerlussuaq in my 4 hour layover there, and walked all of Nuuk in my 2 weeks there. The Nuuk "metro" area is made up of like 3 sub-cities with a bus system connecting them. Assuming whether is permitting (it rained or snowed every other day), there are ample sidewalks and trails to go just about everywhere.
The locals seemed to frown on people leaving the city and exploring outside of the city. Maybe they're tired of tourists getting themselves in trouble or whatever.
There are also ferries that stop off at random villages that you can use to explore, though they weren't running while I was there.

Touched on in my previous posts a bit already, but:
>logistics
>How easy was it to get there and back?
As far as I can tel, the only way to get to Greenland is via either Keflavik, Iceland (Reykjavik's airport), or Copenhagen via Air Greenland's A330 passenger jet.
I did see one plane with a with a Canadian livery, so presumably they fly to Kangerlussuaq from somewhere in Nunavut.
>What about getting around?
Public transit (ie busses) only exist in Nuuk it seems. Walking, biking, snowmachining, 4 wheelers, and cars are the primary forms of travel. Nuuk also had taxis, and Kangerlussuaq had a shuttle operating between the airport and town center.
>Was it easy to book a place to stay?
My experience might be unique, but the my hotel's website wasn't working and I was forced to call and email with the hotel's front desk. The 2 or 3 other hotels seemed to operate the same. So, not terrible, but not ideal.
>How was the internet and did you shitpost on a 4chan board with flags?
Internet was exceptional. Wifi in my room hovered around the 100-200mb mark for down, and like 75 for up. Genuinely impressed with the internet and cell service infrastructure they have there. I don’t know if you’re schizophrenic, but it’s definitely something that does and will actually happen—the two biggest firms where I live have employees from 70+ countries.
>why the fuck would a company go through the hassle of interviewing someone that they know doesn't yet have the necessary permits to work in the country, and then spend the time facilitating the acquisition of said permits and accommodation etc.?
For big companies this is no problem—my wife’s firm actually has leverage with the immigration authorities that makes issuing permits quick and easy. And the firm mostly imports and exports people as internal transfers—someone who already knows the business and brings perspectives or skills from a different market is well worth importing. >>2367481
Depends what you are looking for

Cities here are much less Aesthetic than you can find on the Continent, only Bath stands out off the top of my head.

There aren't really any tourist attractions in other cities, unless you are a fan of history in which case there are numerous Cathedrals and Castles, as well as ruined Abbeys, Castles and Roman stuff. However the latter are in remote areas not hugely accessible by train.

That being said, aesthetic and comfy small towns and villages are in veritable abundance.
So if you want to experience the spirit of 'Old England' I would strongly recommend going to the Cotswolds if this is your thing.

As others have said London is a complete shit tip, but there are some worthwhile things to see, you've got the classic landmarks like Westminster Abbey and the Houses of Parliament. There are other great attractions such as the British Museum and National Portrait Gallery which are free and house lots of well known and remarkable stuff.
